importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication reflects the current urgency of the global need for improved disaster alerts amid escalating extreme weather events in 2025.

This date marks the occurrence of a critical glacier collapse in Switzerland, which demonstrated the life-saving potential of early-warning systems and was cited as a real-world example of successful prediction and evacuation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The year 2025 is highlighted as a period of intense weather-related disasters globally, including floods and wildfires, reinforcing the urgency of early-warning systems in the face of climate change.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather, leaving millions—particularly in developing nations—vulnerable.
Disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, with 90% of deaths in the past 50 years occurring in developing countries.
Over 2 million people have died from weather, water, and climate-related hazards in the last 50 years.
While 108 countries now use some form of multi-hazard early warning systems (up from 52), half still have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most severe in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries establishing functioning early-warning websites and standardized alert systems.
Early warning enables early action, and the WMO’s goal is not only to warn but to empower communities to respond effectively.
Recent disasters in 2025, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, underscore the global scale of climate-driven risks.
Swiss scientists successfully predicted a glacier collapse in May 2025, allowing evacuation of the village of Blatten, demonstrating the value of real-time monitoring and early warnings.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO), a UN agency, has issued a global appeal to improve early-warning systems for extreme weather, emphasizing that nearly half of all countries lack adequate monitoring and forecasting capabilities. The WMO reports that over 2 million people have died from weather-related disasters in the past 50 years, with 90% of deaths occurring in developing nations. Despite progress—such as an increase in countries using multi-hazard early warning systems from 52 to 108—many regions still have only basic or no capacity, especially in fragile and conflict-affected areas. The article highlights real-world examples, including the 2025 glacier collapse in Switzerland that led to the evacuation of the village of Blatten, and severe weather disasters in Pakistan, Nigeria, South Korea, and the US, illustrating the global scale and urgency of climate-driven risks. The WMO stresses that early warnings must empower communities to act, and that climate change is intensifying weather events, making proactive preparedness essential for global safety.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather 'spirals'
